stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session prototyping a new shoreline-water system (waves that flatten near land and a dynamic foam layer) while briefly attempting a sound-effect engine upgrade. He also explains an old Mario 64 sound bug and vents about emulator issues.
level: Coastal overworld level (working title mentioned as "cove"/shore area)

development_findings.summary: Kaze is adding the ability for two sound effects from the same bank to play simultaneously, which will "seriously improve the sound-effect quality across the board" but was postponed after running into complexity.
development_findings.quote: Basically what I'm trying to do is make it so that two sound effects per bank can play at the same time. This would seriously improve the sound effect quality across the board.

development_findings.summary: He solved the famous low-pitched boo noise in Big Boo’s Haunt: the ‘boo laugh’ is baked into the wind sample with a 299-frame delay; when the sound is prematurely cancelled (e.g., door transition) the boo layer plays at full volume.
development_findings.quote: The truth is actually so much more messed up… the boolaugh is just a part of the wind sound effect and placed at the very end of the sound.

development_findings.summary: New shoreline system: waves now use vertex scalars to reduce amplitude near land; foam is a separate clamped texture that scrolls on a sine wave and fades with vertex alpha. Spare bits of the red vertex channel store pre-computed wave height.
development_findings.quote: We could use the lower bits of the red channel for the wave height. I think that might genuinely be our best option.

development_findings.summary: Water rendering upgraded to two-cycle combiner with directional wave motion; ROM currently ~59 MB, still acceptable.
Need ‘material labels’ in the exporter; without them Kaze plans a startup routine that searches display-list commands after a texture pointer to insert scroll operations.
development_findings.quote: If we don’t get material labels, I’m going to make a function that finds the first tile-size command after the texture pointer.

development_findings.summary: Engine memory layout: Z-buffer sits next to rarely-read graph-node data so extra models (e.g., fish) are ‘basically free’.
development_findings.quote: By doing it this way… the fish is basically entirely free and it's mostly living in a memory region that goes unused.

development_findings.summary: Gameplay statistics (jumps, stamps, playtime, deaths, damage, coins, savestates) are already being recorded for possible end-game display.
Current content status: final Bowser fight and ~5 side levels still missing; overall progress slowed because Kaze focused on engine upgrades rather than new courses.
development_findings.quote: We’re still missing the final Bowser, we’re missing like five side levels. You’re gonna have to wait.

development_findings.summary: ROM size sits at 59 MB; parallel-N64 emulator still crashes because it formerly could not address the last byte of memory (off-by-one bug Kaze helped identify).
development_findings.quote: The bug was that you couldn’t use the last byte in memory because of an off by one error.

context_findings.summary: Kaze keeps a private repo with ten trusted people so the project survives him; believes "the value is in what I make" rather than in his own life.
context_findings.quote: There’s like 10 people that have access to Return to Yoshi’s Island… nothing would be lost if I died.

context_findings.summary: Avoids AI tools on the project to prevent backlash from fans even though he sees autocomplete utility.
context_findings.quote: People will get really mad at me if I do anything AI… definitely not enough to justify people being upset at me.

context_findings.summary: He detests 2-D platformers and Mario World, saying he’d only hack it by changing the core fun completely.
context_findings.quote: I absolutely hate 2D platformers… I would have a really hard time coming up with an answer because I don’t find any joy in that game.

context_findings.summary: Expresses nihilistic philosophy (life has no inherent value) and recounts near-dog attack incident.
context_findings.quote: I don’t think there’s an inherent value in life, but that’s just me.

context_findings.summary: Would go full-time on the hack if patron support covered living costs; current finances complicated by tax laws.
context_findings.quote: If you have enough patrons around us, would you do this full time? – Yes, actually, yes, for sure, yes.

context_findings.summary: Attempts to dodge political discourse by labeling it ‘culture-war distraction’, preferring to focus on game development.
context_findings.quote: My new excuse… I will say it’s all culture war and I will not be discussing any culture-war issues.

biobak.summary: Sets visual targets for the new shoreline; expects to redo placeholder textures and UV maps once Kaze’s technical base is ready.
biobak.quote: Well, Biobak is probably going to change it anyway, so don’t worry if you don’t like it right now.

biobak.summary: Requested large waves far from shore and flat water near land; Kaze implemented height scaling accordingly.
biobak.quote: I think this is exactly what Biobak wanted. We got big waves over there and then small waves here.

zeina.summary: Appears only briefly, sending Kaze photos of a region they visited; no direct project work discussed.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Booloth Sound Glitch
key_stories.summary: An infamous low-pitch boo heard in Big Boo’s Haunt puzzled players for years. On stream, Kaze disassembled the original sample bank and proved the boo laugh is embedded at the tail of the wind sample with huge delays, only audible when playback is interrupted.
key_stories.challenge: Determine why a ‘boo’ plays when Mario exits the merry-go-round room.
key_stories.process: Examined sample list, located wind instrument bank 6, instrument 9; showed frame delays and door-triggered cancellation.
key_stories.outcome: Definitive technical explanation; no code change yet but myth debunked.
key_stories.key_quote: The boolaugh is just part of the wind sound effect… usually you never hear it, but when you cancel the sound effect you do.

key_stories.title: Parallel Emulator Memory Bug
key_stories.summary: A demo crash in the Parallel-N64 emulator forced Kaze to collaborate with developer Falco. They traced it to an off-by-one error that prevented use of the last RAM byte, but many players never got the patched build.
key_stories.challenge: RTYI demo crashed for users on Parallel-N64.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Falco debugged, found emulator couldn’t address final byte; Kaze adjusted decompression heap but fix relied on emulator update.
key_stories.outcome: Bug fixed upstream yet players still affected; Kaze remains frustrated and avoids Parallel.
key_stories.key_quote: This wouldn’t have been a problem if they didn’t test in production.

key_stories.title: Engineering Realistic Shore Foam
key_stories.summary: To make coastlines believable, Kaze built a new shader system: wave heights stored in vertex color bits, amplitude reduced near shore, and a clamped scrolling foam texture fades based on wave height.
key_stories.challenge: Previous water lacked convincing interaction with land.
key_stories.process: Mapped wave height to vertex scalars; repurposed red-channel bits; designed sine-wave scroll and two-cycle combiner; iterated live with Biobak and chat.
key_stories.outcome: Prototype working in-engine; Biobak will refine art.
key_stories.key_quote: We could use the lower bits of the red channel for the wave height — that might genuinely be our best option.

open_questions.context: Kaze introduced idea but postponed implementation.
questions: How will two-per-bank playback be scheduled without exhausting channels?
Which gameplay scenarios currently suffer most from the limitation?
What milestones remain before this feature ships?

open_questions.context: Current lack forces Kaze to write a startup hack to find tile-size commands.
questions: Is Lilaa planning to expose material tags?
How would proper labels change artist workflow for Biobak?
What technical debt accrues if workaround stays?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated these areas are still missing.
questions: What design ideas exist for the final Bowser battle?
How many side levels and what themes are planned?

open_questions.context: Engine captures jumps, stamps, playtime, etc.
questions: How will these stats be surfaced to players?
Do they influence unlockables or purely informational?
Will they feed into speedrun leaderboards?

open_questions.context: Kaze avoids AI to prevent backlash.
questions: Would limited AI (e.g., code autocomplete) ever be acceptable?
How does the team balance efficiency with community perception?
Has the stance affected recruiting contributors?

open_questions.context: Kaze would go full-time if patronage allowed; tax laws complicate income.
questions: What patronage level enables full-time focus?
How much time does Kaze currently allocate weekly?
What legal/tax hurdles exist for making the project a primary job?
